Exploring economic-efficient bifunctional catalysts is critical for the production of green hydrogen through water splitting. Herein, we fabricate a novel hybrid catalyst with three-phase heterojunction (Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO) via a simple electrodeposition and chemical precipitation method. Benefiting from the desirable amorphous-crystal interfaces, the electronic structure of Ni, NiO and Fe(OH)3 is regulated, which will optimize the adsorption of H intermediates (H*) and also reduce the kinetic barrier for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). The optimal Fe(OH)3–3/Ni-NiO/CC shows superior bifunctional activity with low overpotentials of 66 mV for HER and 220 mV for OER at 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline solution, respectively, as well as remarkable durability over a period of 40 h. Besides, Fe(OH)3–3/Ni-NiO/CC requires 1.52 and 1.72 V to deliver 10 and 100 mA cm−2 and shows no obvious increase in current within 40 h toward overall water splitting. Experimental and theoretical results show that the HER process is promoted by the synergistic effect of electronic redistribution between Ni, NiO and Fe(OH)3 due to the construction of three phase crystalline-amorphous heterogeneous interface. Meanwhile, Fe(OH)3 and NiO appeared reconstruction, transforming into FeOOH and NiOOH during OER process, respectively. This work offers a simple synthesis method for designing bifunctional catalysts for water splitting. Graphical abstract We fabricate a novel hybrid catalyst with three-phase heterojunction (Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO) via a simple electrodeposition and chemical precipitation method. The optimal Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC shows superior bifunctional activity at 10 and 100 mA cm−2 with voltages of 1.52 and 1.88 V for overall water splitting and no obvious increase in current within 40 h. Image, graphical abstract Key words (Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO) Multiphase heterostructure Bifunctional electrocatalyst Over water splitting Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction The production and utilization of hydrogen energy from renewable sources has become one of the most important directions for achieving carbon peak and carbon neutrality in the future [1-3]. At present, alkaline water electrolysis is regarded a more environmentally friendly, efficient and economical route to generate clean and high purity hydrogen, especially using the electricity from renewable energy sources including wind, solar and power generation from water [4-7]. Alkaline water electrolysis involves two half reactions including hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [8,9]. Nevertheless, the reaction kinetics for OER is sluggish and the water adsorption and dissociation for HER is weak, resulting in high overpotentials, which limits the large-scale industrial applications [10,11]. Thus, it is imperative to design efficient electrocatalysts for reducing the overpotentials and improving the kinetics. In this regard, noble metal Pt and Ru or Ir oxides catalysts are deemed as the benchmark catalysts for water splitting. Nevertheless, the scarcity, high price, and poor stability of precious metal catalysts hamper their wide application [12-14]. As a consequence, it is extremely significant to exploit high activity, low-cost, and durable nonprecious metal bifunctional catalysts for reducing electrode costs and simplifying the design of overall water electrolyser system [15-17]. Several non-precious metal oxides including Ni, Co, Mn, and Fe oxides have been considered potential catalysts for alkaline electrolytic water on account of the low water dissociation energy for HER and the low activation energy barriers for OER active intermediate (OOH*) [18-22]. However, the HER and OER properties of transition-metal oxides are poor because of the bad electrical conductivity and small active surface area. Several strategies such as conductive carbon supports, heterojunction, defective engineering, and so on have been confirmed to be feasible methods to enhance their performance for water splitting [23]. Simultaneously, due to the well electrical conductivity of metal Ni and the synergistic effect between NiO and Ni, numerous NiO@Ni compounds were viewed as electrocatalysts for HER or OER [24]. Li and co-workers supposed that NiO expedited the Volmer step while metallic Ni improved the Heyrovsky/Tafel step through theoretical calculation [17]. Chen et al. demonstrated that crystalline/amorphous Ni-NiO with core-shell structure exhibited superior HER activity at 5 mA cm−2 with an overpotential of 110 mV, which was attributed to the synergistic effect of the Ni core and the amorphous NiO shell [25]. To improve the unsatisfactory conductivity of NiO, Tang et al. prepared a Ni-NiO heterojunction using an interface engineering method. The obtained Ni-NiO150 presented a small overpotential of 280 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for OER [26]. The electronic interaction and redistribution at the heterojunction interface overcame the sluggishness of reaction and enhanced the conductivity of the catalyst, thus accelerate the catalytic activity of the catalyst [27]. However, it suffered from poor activity or stability when it was used as a bifunctional catalyst for HER and OER in the same electrolyte. Recent studies revealed that the introduction of highly active OER components into the above Ni-NiO compounds could improve the electrocatalytic water splitting properties. For instance, Hu et al. introduced Mo oxide into Ni-NiO system by electrodeposition. The experimental and computational results jointly proved that Ni-NiO and MoO3 NiO heterostructures selectively served as the catalytic sites for HER and OER, significantly reducing the energy barrier and synergically accelerating the entire water splitting process [28]. Yan et al. revealed that the doping of Fe3O4 species accelerated charge-transfer kinetics and increased more active sites. The obtained Ni/NiO/Fe3O4 showed a small overpotential of 258 mV for OER and 206 mV for HER, which was significantly lower than the prepared Ni-NiO [29]. Herein, we synthesized a novel amorphous-crystalline Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO/CC composite with three-phase heterojunction by a simple electrodeposition and chemical precipitation method. In this bifunctional catalyst, introducing crystalline Fe(OH)3 into the Ni and NiO heterostructures could create abundant three-phases heterostructure interfaces, which were beneficial for increasing more active sites, speeding up the electron transfer process, and thereby improving the catalytic performance for HER and OER. The first-principle calculations indicated that the electrons at the Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO heterojunctions interface were redistributed, which could balance Gibbs adsorption free energy of H* and lowered energy barrier for water dissociation. As expected, the prepared Fe(OH)3–3/Ni-NiO/CC exhibited small overpotentials at 10 mA cm−2 for HER (66 mV) and OER (220 mV). Besides, the Fe(OH)3–3/Ni-NiO/CC heterojunction showed a low water splitting voltage at 10 mA cm−2 (1.52 V) and 100 mA cm−2 (1.88 V) while the current exhibited no obvious increase within 40 h. Therefore, this work supplied a prospective path for preparing three-phase heterojunction as a highly active bifunctional catalyst for water splitting. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O were purchased from Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., LTD. KOH was bought from Tianjin Shengao Chemical Reagent Co., LTD. Anhydrous ethanol was obtained from Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., LTD. Commercial Pt/C (20 wt%) and ruthenium oxide (RuO2) were obtained by Shanghai Chuxi Industrial Company. Carbon cloth was purchased from Sai Bo Electrochemical Materials. All materials were not further purified. 2.2 Preparation of Ni-NiO/CC The carbon cloth (CC) was activated by nitric acid, and then rinsed using acetone, ethanol and deionized water, respectively. The pre-treated carbon cloth was used as the working electrode, Hg/HgO electrode and graphite rod served as reference electrode and counter electrode, respectively. The electrodeposition solution consisted of 20 mM Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O. The electrodeposition process was performed for 30 min at voltage of −3 V vs Hg/HgO [28]. Finally, the prepared electrode was rinsed and then dried in a vacuum oven for 6 h at 60 °C to acquire Ni-NiO/CC (Ni-NiO-2/CC) electrode. In addition, Ni-NiO-1/CC, Ni-NiO-3/CC and Ni-NiO-4/CC electrodes were prepared by the same electrodeposition method at different deposition times (15, 45 and 60 min) at −3 V vs SCE. 2.3 Preparation of (Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO)/CC electrode The prepared Ni-NiO/CC electrode was immersed in 30 mL of 0.75 mmol/L Fe(NO3)3 solution, and then 10 mL of 1 M KOH solution was dropped into the above solution and left for 4 h. After the reaction finished, the obtained Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO/CC electrode was rinsed and dried at 60 °C for 4 h. The detailed preparation route was illustrated in Fig. 1. According to the concentration of Fe(NO3)3 (0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0, and 1.25 mM), the final samples were labeled as Fe(OH)3-1/Ni-NiO/CC, Fe(OH)3-2/Ni-NiO/CC, Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC, Fe(OH)3-4/Ni-NiO/CC and Fe(OH)3-5/Ni-NiO/CC, respectively. For comparison, the Fe(OH)3/CC electrode was also prepared on CF under the same conditions without Ni-NiO. 2.4 Preparation of RuO2 and Pt/C electrodes To prepare RuO2/CC and Pt/C/CC electrodes for performance comparison, the commercial 20 % Pt/C and RuO2 powders were drop-coated on the carbon cloth (CC). Typically, 4 mg of RuO2 or Pt/C was dispersed in solution containing 500 μL of ethanol, 480 µL of deionized water and 20 µL of Nafion (5 wt%) followed by sonication for 30 min at room temperature. After that, 500 µL of dispersion was coated onto CC (1 × 2 cm2) and dried at room temperature. The catalyst load was about 1.0 mg cm−2. 2.5 Materials characterization The prepared electrodes were tested by X-ray power diffraction patterns (XRD) with Cu Kα radiation across a 2θ range of 5–90° The morphology of the composite electrodes was observed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, ZEISS Sigma 300) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI Talos F200S). The elemental composition and valence state of the catalysts were characterized by Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR, iS50) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (ESCALAB 250Xi) equipped with Al Kα X-ray radiation. 2.6 Electrochemical performance test All electrochemical characterizations were carried via a CHI760E electrochemical workstation with a conventional three-electrode system in 1.0 M KOH. For HER and OER, the prepared catalyst samples served as the working electrode, and using Hg/HgO and carbon rod as reference electrode and counter electrode, respectively. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) at scan rates of 5 mV s −1 with iR compensation (85 %) was used to evaluate the catalyst activity for HER or OER. The Tafel plot was obtained by LSV curve fitting. Electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) was calculated from the double layer capacitance (Cdl) charging curve, which was obtained from the CV curve test in the non-faradaic region at different scanning rates of 20, 40, 60, 80, 100 and 120 mV s −1. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was measured at frequency of 0.01–105 Hz. All potentials were converted to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) ( E ( R H E ) = E ( H g H g O ) + 0.098 V + 0.0591 × p H ). The electrochemical stability of the electrode for water splitting was evaluated by measuring the change of current with time using chronoamperometry. 2.7 Density functional theory calculations All adsorption configurations were calculated by DS-PAW software [30] with the GGA-PBE method [31,32]. The optimized configuration was convergence when the energy and force were less than or equal 10−5 eV and 0.02 eV Å. The convergence criteria were set to 10−5 eV for the energy and 0.02 eV Å for the force. The smearing value was set to 0.1 eV for self-consistent field convergence. Ni-NiO (111) was simulated by three layers with a 5 × 5 supercell. The Brillouin zone integration was implemented with 2 × 2 × 1 k-point sampling. The cutoff energy was set as 400 eV in all calculation processes. The above methods have been widely used in catalytic areas [33-36]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and structure characterization of Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO/CC The fabrication procedure of Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO/CC was obtained via a two-step sequential electrodeposition and chemical precipitation method, as shown in Fig. 1 . Primarily, Ni-NiO composite was grown on conductive carbon cloth via one step electrodeposition. During this procedure, Ni2+ ions will involve the following reactions N i 2 + + 2 e − → N i , N i 2 + + 2 O H − → N i ( O H ) 2 , and N i ( O H ) 2 → N i O + H 2 O . After the Ni-NiO composite was loaded on the CC, Fe(OH)3 was directly deposited on Ni-NiO composite by chemical precipitation. The morphology characterization of Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO/CC was studied by SEM. As shown in Fig. 2 a, Ni-NiO nanosheets with flower-like were evenly grown on the carbon cloth, while Fe(OH)3 prepared by chemical precipitation accumulated into irregular spherical particles on the surface of the carbon cloth (Fig. 2b). After Ni-NiO was bound to Fe(OH)3 to form the Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO complex with a unique coralloid structure (Fig. 2c). Obviously, the size of Ni-NiO decreased after Fe(OH)3 deposition. In order to analyze the reasons, the Ni-NiO/CC electrode was impregnated in Fe(NO3)3 solution for 4 h, and the pretreated Ni-NiO/CC was characterized by SEM. As shown in Fig. S1, the particle size and morphology of Ni-NiO after Fe(NO3)3 impregnation could be obviously observed. It may be due to the hydrolysis of Fe(NO3)3 to form part H+ and NO3 −, resulting in Ni-NiO etching [37]. In addition, the irregular spherical Fe(OH)3 prepared by chemical precipitation on the Ni-NiO surface would also cause Ni-NiO to be covered. It was worth noting that, a variety of control experiments were also studied. Fig. S2 showed the SEM images of Fe(OH)3-X/Ni-NiO/CC prepared with different ferric nitrate concentrations. It could be seen that Fe(OH)3-1/Ni-NiO/CC presented irregular clusters when the concentration of ferric nitrate was too low. As the concentration increased, the clusters were separated and evenly distributed, and gradually form holes. When the concentration of ferric nitrate solution increased further, more Fe(OH)3 species gradually covered Ni-NiO, resulting in a gradual decline in its catalytic activity. As reported, Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO with coralloid structure could supply more active sites and abundant pores, which were quite beneficial for water splitting. Similarly, the corresponding TEM microstructural analysis of Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO was provided in Fig. 2d and revealed the accumulation structure of Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO, which was consistent with the SEM observations. Obviously, the corresponding high-resolution TEM (Fig. 2f) showed that the three-phase heterojunction interface between Ni, NiO and Fe(OH)3 was clearly visible. The lattice fringe spacing was 0.204 and 0.267 nm, which belonged to the (111) crystal plane of Ni and the (202) crystal plane of Fe(OH)3, respectively. In addition, NiO in the form of amorphous structure was also observed, indicating that the existence of three-phase heterojunction between amorphous NiO and crystal Ni and Fe(OH)3 [38]. In the SAED pattern (Fig. 2e), distinct bright spots were observed, ascribing to the (111) and (200) planes of Ni and (422) plane of Fe(OH)3 [39], demonstrating the existence of crystalline Ni and Fe(OH)3. Moreover, the elemental mappings revealed that Ni, Fe and O elements were evenly distributed, indicating that the three-phase heterojunction was closely intertwined (Fig. 2g). To identify the crystal structure of the prepared samples, XRD patterns were performed. As depicted in Fig. 3 a, for the obtaining Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO/CC and Ni-NiO/CC, the three diffraction peaks at 44.5°, 51.8° and 76.4° were ascribed to the (111), (200) and (220) planes, which was consistent with the typical Ni crystal structure (JCPDS 04-0850). The wide peak at 25° belonged to the characteristic (002) peak of the bare carbon cloth [40-42]. However, no peaks of NiO were detected in both Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO/CC and Ni-NiO/CC, which further proved that NiO existed in an amorphous state [24]. Besides, the diffraction peaks at 33.4°, 37.6° and 59.8° ascribed to the (202), (130) and (422) crystal planes of Fe(OH)3 (PDF#46-1436) were observed, which confirmed that Fe(OH)3 embedded in Ni-NiO. Moreover, after the combination of Ni-NiO and Fe(OH)3, the diffraction peaks of Ni were significantly weakened (Fig. S3), possibly due to the successful coating of Fe(OH)3. In addition, the content of Fe and Ni in Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO/CC samples by ICP was 0.08 % and 9.01 %, respectively. Subsequently, the compositional information of the materials was tested by FTIR spectra. As shown in Fig. 3b, the vibration peak near 702 cm−1 was assignable to the vibration mode of Ni-O, verifying the formation of NiO in the composite materials [43,44]. The predominant peaks near 1361 cm−1 and 1653 cm−1 were ascribed to the OH vibrations of H2O molecule [45,46]. It was clearly observed that the new peaks near 880 cm−1 and 1061 cm−1 for Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO/CC electrode, which were due to the bending vibration of Fe-OH and Fe(-OH)2Fe, respectively [47,48]. Besides, the OH stretching vibration was observed in the region of 3100–3300 cm−1. These results confirmed the presence of Fe(OH)3 covered on the Ni-NiO surface. To analyze the chemical component and valence state of the prepared Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO/CC, the XPS spectra were performed. As seen from Fig. 3c, for the Fe 2p spectrum of Fe(OH)3/CC, the peaks with binding energy centered at around 710.9 eV and 724.1 eV, along with two vibrational satellite peaks near at 716.3 eV and 730.6 eV were associated to Fe3+, confirming the oxidation state of Fe3+ for Fe(OH)3/CC. Compared with that of Fe(OH)3/CC, the Fe 2p spectrum of Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO/CC showed a 0.53 eV positive shift, indicating that Fe could serve as a donor. It was confirmed that the presence of Ni forced Fe into a higher oxidation state, and the high chemical oxidation state was more conducive to optimizing the adsorption of intermediates during the OER process, resulting in excellent electrochemical properties [49]. In Fig. 3d, the Ni 2p XPS spectrum of Ni-NiO/CC showed two peaks at 853.0 and 870.1 eV, indicating the presence of metallic Ni. Besides, there were two peaks at 856.2 and 873.8 eV corresponding to the Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 of Ni2+orbitals of NiO, along with two shake-up satellite peaks at 861.8 and 879.9 eV, respectively, indicating that the formation of Ni and NiO on the CC. It was worth to point out that the binding energies of the Ni2+ peaks in Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO/CC showed a negative shift after the introduction of Fe(OH)3, proving an electron-rich state around the NiO. The above XPS results demonstrated the interaction between Fe(OH)3 and Ni-NiO resulted in the charge redistribution. 3.2 Electrocatalytic properties 3.2.1 OER performance Electrocatalytic performances of the prepared materials toward OER were tested via a three-electrode system. As shown in Fig. S4A, the LSV polarization curves of Ni-NiO-X/CC catalysts for OER was first tested. The obtained Ni-NiO-2/CC by electrodeposition for 30 min under −3 V vs SCE condition showed better OER activity. In the process of electrocatalytic water oxidation, it was also observed in the electrocatalytic water oxidation process, Ni-NiO catalyst has obvious anodic oxidation peak on the LSV curves, which can be ascribed to the transition from low oxidation (Ni2+) to high oxidation (Ni3+). Therefore, so as to reduce the potential influence of Ni2+ oxidation during the OER process, the LSV sweeping test was performed from high potential to low potential. As shown in Fig. 4 a, it was found that Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC showed better OER activity with an overpotential of 220 mV at 10 mA cm−2 after optimizing the concentration of Fe(NO3)3. As expected, it was even much lower than the pure Ni-NiO/CC (275 mV), Fe(OH)3/CC (388 mV) and RuO2/CC (339 mV) (Fig. 4B), indicating that the synergistic effect of Ni-NiO and Fe(OH)3 was beneficial to promote the OER properties of the composite. In addition, Fe(OH)3–3/Ni-NiO/CC showed smaller Tafel slope (52.9 mV dec−1) compared to Fe(OH)3/CC (103.0 mV dec−1) and Ni-NiO/CC (77.5 mV dec−1) (Fig. 4c), manifesting that electrochemical water oxidation kinetics of Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC was more faster. To further unravel the improvement of OER performance of the prepared catalyst, EIS tests were performed. As shown in Fig. 4d, it was obvious that Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO/CC revealed the smallest charge transfer resistance (Rct, 7.62 Ω), indicating a fast charge transfer ability for OER process. To probe the intrinsic activity of Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC heterostructure, ECSA was assessed utilizing the Cdl, which was measured by the CV curves at different scan rates (Fig. S5). Clearly, compared with Ni-NiO/CC (1.96 mF cm−2) and Fe(OH)3/CC (0.58 mF cm−2), the Cdl value of Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC heterojunction was high (5.98 mF cm−2), indicated that the heterojunction could significantly improve the ECSA of the catalyst (Fig. 4e), and thus promoted the OER activity. Moreover, the stability of Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC was assessed using chronoamperometry method. From this analysis in Fig. 4f, the current density barely changed, demonstrating the good OER stability of the catalyst. The above results showed that Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC exhibited a good OER activity and stability. 3.2.2 HER performance Furthermore, the HER properties of the material were also measured and the method was basically consistent with the OER process. As shown in Fig. S4B, the LSV polarization curves of Ni-NiO-X/CC catalysts for HER was tested. The obtained Ni-NiO-2/CC by electrodeposition for 30 min under −3 V vs SCE condition showed better HER activity. Therefore, Ni-NiO-2/CC was selected as the pre-catalyst for deposition Fe(OH)3. In Fig. 5 a, the Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC electrode prepared at different Fe(NO3)3 concentrations showed the smallest overpotential. In particular, Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC only needed 66 mV and 155 mV to reach 10 mA cm−2 and 50 mA cm−2 for HER. It was markedly smaller than those of the pure Ni-NiO/CC (126 mV and 464 mV) and Fe(OH)3/CC (217 mV and 566 mV) (Fig. 5b-c), but the HER activity was relatively poor compared with the commercial Pt/C (30 mV and 72 mV). In Fig. 5D, the HER kinetics was analysed by using Tafel plots. The Tafel slope was 97.3 mV dec−1 for Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC, which was much lower than Ni-NiO/CC (140.7 mV dec−1) and Fe(OH)3/CC (159.9 mV dec−1). The results showed that Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC exhibited faster reaction kinetics due to the construction of three phase heterojunction. Additionally, the corresponding Nyquist plots showed that the Nyquist curve radius of Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC was also small, The corresponding Rct was 3.95 Ω (Fig. 5e), demonstrating a faster electron transport rate for HER. Furthermore, the durability of the Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC was analysed via chronoamperometry method in 1 M KOH. As can be seen from Fig. 5f, the Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC electrode showed a negligible decay after running for 40 h, indicating that the Fe(OH)3–3/Ni-NiO/CC exhibited good HER stability. 3.2.3 Overall water splitting performance Combined with the above experimental results, the Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC heterostructure possessed advantages in both OER and HER. Therefore, the Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC was directly served as anode and cathode to assess the overall water splitting properties. In Fig. 6 a, the dual electrodes Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC||Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC only required small cell voltages of 1.52 V and 1.72 V to deliver 10 and 100 mA cm−2, which was much lower than the dual electrodes RuO2/CC(+)||Pt/C/CC (1.72 V and 2.39 V). Besides, compared with the non-precious metal catalysts reported in recent years (Table S1), the Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC electrode showed superior water splitting properties. Meanwhile, the long-term water splitting process of the catalyst was tested by using a two-electrode system. As described in Fig. 6b, the Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC displayed prominent stability with no decrease significantly within 40 h at 10 mA cm−2, indicating that the Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC electrode as a bifunctional catalyst showed good water decomposition performance and durability. The faradaic efficiency (FE) of Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC electrode was calculated by testing the volume of H2 and O2 using Hofmann device. As shown in Fig. S6, the H2 and O2vol were 26.7 mL and 13.7 mL, respectively, after 4200 s test. The faraday values were calculated to be 95.31 % and 90.78 %, respectively, which indicated that the Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC electrode had potential of practical industrial application. 3.3 Analysis of catalytic mechanism of OER In order to explore the internal mechanism of OER performance improvement, in-situ Raman experiments were carried out. As shown in Fig. 7 , there were three peaks at 432, 501 and 536 cm−1, which belonged to the NiO of the initial Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC [50,51]. When the applied potential was 0.4 V vs Hg/HgO, three peaks of NiO disappeared, while new peaks appeared at 267, 457 and 548 cm−1. The results showed that NiO was converted to NiOOH. Fe(OH)3 may transform to FeOOH during OER [52-54]. As expected, the peaks intensity of NiOOH and FeOOH gradually increased as the potential increased from 0.40 V vs Hg/HgO to 0.7 V vs Hg/HgO, indicating a potentially-induced transition. At the same time, the formation of NiOOH and FeOOH remained almost constant during the OER process, which may be the reason for the excellent OER performance of the catalyst. Moreover, SEM and XPS tests of Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC were conducted after OER process, and the results were shown in Fig. S7. After OER process, there was an obvious layer of amorphous material on the surface of the particles, which may be due to the oxidation of the catalyst during the OER, resulting in NiOOH and FeOOH. In addition, the Ni3+ was found in the XPS results of Ni 2p. It was further confirmed that Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC transformed into NiOOH during the reaction. 3.4 DFT calculations To clarified the catalytic mechanism of HER activity of Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO/CC catalyst in alkaline electrolyte, a three-phase heterogeneous structure model of Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO/CC catalyst was constructed. The molecular model was shown in Fig. S8. Firstly, DFT was used to calculate the adsorption free energy of the catalyst for H2O (Fig. 8 a), and it was obtained that the adsorption free energy of Ni-NiO, Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO for H2O was −0.38 eV and −0.62 eV, respectively. The Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO had higher negative adsorption free energy, indicating that the three-phase heterojunction catalyst showed the ability to rapidly adsorb water and was more conducive to activating OH bonds in H2O [55]. Based on the DFT calculation of the adsorption energy of H* (Fig. 8b), the adsorption free energy of Ni-NiO and Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO catalysts for H* adsorption was −0.34 eV and −0.27 eV, respectively. Too high adsorption free energy of H* was not good for the subsequent desorption. The H* adsorption free energy of Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO was much smaller, indicating that Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO showed the best adsorption kinetics. Fig. 8(C-D) revealed the charge density distribution of water molecules adsorbed in different catalyst structure models, clearly revealed the polarization configuration of water molecules [56]. The results showed that H2O transfered 0.083 e to Ni-NiO and 0.109 e to Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO. The differential charge distribution of Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO showed that one side of Fe(OH)3 was a charge depletion region on one side, while the other side of Ni-NiO was a charge accumulation region [57]. Fig. 8e showed the charge transfer between Fe(OH)3 and Ni-NiO. There were about 1.054 charges transferred from Fe(OH)3 to the Ni-NiO surface, resulting in an electron-rich state around Ni-NiO. This result was consistent with the XPS result, where Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO/CC possessed more free electrons to promote the conversion of H* to H2. In summary, DFT calculation proved that Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO with three-phase heterostructure synergistically improved alkaline HER activity by regulating electronic structure as well as optimizing the adsorption capability of H*. 4 Conclusion In this study, we fabricated Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO on carbon cloth by using a facile electrodeposition and chemical precipitation method. The prepared Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO was a three-phase heterojunction structure composed of amorphous NiO and crystalline Ni and Fe(OH)3. The optimized Fe(OH)3–3/Ni-NiO/CC electrode exhibited prominent catalytic activities and durability simultaneously towards OER (220 mV, 10 mA cm−2) and HER (66 mV, 10 mA cm−2) in alkaline solution. Meanwhile, Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC only needed cell voltage of 1.52 V to attain a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and exhibited robust stability (40 h) for electrochemical water decomposition. The improved performance of Fe(OH)3-3/Ni-NiO/CC electrode can be ascribed to the fast charge/mass transport and electronic regulation induced by heterostructure. The DFT results revealed that three-phase heterojunction structure not only could facilitate the water dissociation, but also optimized the adsorption energy of H* from the distinct electronic structure at the interface. Hence, this work presented a novel strategy for designing bifunctional electrocatalysts for water splitting. coredata.dc:description: Exploring economic-efficient bifunctional catalysts is critical for the production of green hydrogen through water splitting. Herein, we fabricate a novel hybrid catalyst with three-phase heterojunction (Fe(OH)3/Ni-NiO) via a simple electrodeposition and chemical precipitation method. Benefiting from the desirable amorphous-crystal interfaces, the electronic structure of Ni, NiO and Fe(OH)3 is regulated, which will optimize the adsorption of H intermediates (H*) and also reduce the kinetic barrier for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). The optimal Fe(OH)3–3/Ni-NiO/CC shows superior bifunctional activity with low overpotentials of 66 mV for HER and 220 mV for OER at 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline solution, respectively, as well as remarkable durability over a period of 40 h. Besides, Fe(OH)3–3/Ni-NiO/CC requires 1.52 and 1.72 V to deliver 10 and 100 mA cm−2 and shows no obvious increase in current within 40 h toward overall water splitting. Experimental and theoretical results show that the HER process is promoted by the synergistic effect of electronic redistribution between Ni, NiO and Fe(OH)3 due to the construction of three phase crystalline-amorphous heterogeneous interface. Meanwhile, Fe(OH)3 and NiO appeared reconstruction, transforming into FeOOH and NiOOH during OER process, respectively. This work offers a simple synthesis method for designing bifunctional catalysts for water splitting.
